title: 112_s2275
content: The Act is titled the "Broadband Connections for Rural Opportunities Program Act of 2012" or the "B-CROP Act of 2012." It amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to establish the Broadband Connections for Rural Opportunities Program. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as broadband service, eligible entity, and eligible rural community. Eligible entities include private sector providers and various government or nonprofit organizations. Eligible rural communities are defined as areas in the United States that are not within certain boundaries. The grant program aims to enhance broadband service in rural communities without private investment feasibility, focusing on areas outside urbanized regions with populations over 50,000. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for broadband services in rural communities, with grants not exceeding 50% of project costs. Eligible entities must submit an application to receive a grant, and funds must be used for deploying broadband networks in targeted areas. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for broadband services in rural communities, focusing on unserved eligible rural areas. Priority will be given to projects that serve the highest proportion of rural residents without broadband access and stimulate rural economic development. The Secretary will award grants for broadband services in rural communities, focusing on unserved areas to stimulate economic development by connecting businesses and organizations at the county and regional levels. Grant recipients must submit a report to the Secretary. The Secretary will award grants for broadband services in rural communities, focusing on unserved areas to stimulate economic development. Recipients must submit a report on fund usage. The Secretary will provide biannual reports on planned and actual fund obligations until all funds are spent. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2012 through 2014. Improving the application process for the rural broadband program. The Rural Electrification Act of 1936 is amended to reduce paperwork for applicants and establish a 180-day processing period for grant awards under the rural broadband program. The Rural Electrification Act of 1936 is amended to simplify the application process and establish a 180-day processing period for grant awards under the rural broadband program. The amendments include conducting outreach to inform areas with limited broadband service and allowing the Secretary to hire additional staff using up to 20% of the budget authority. The Rural Electrification Act of 1936 is amended to simplify application and audit requirements for subsidiaries, allowing for a consolidated application or audit report to be filed by parent companies and wholly owned subsidiaries. The application/report must contain all financial details related to the project for the grant, loan, or loan guarantee. The Secretary will review the business plan, revenue sources, and projections of each applicant to ensure no conflicts exist. The applicant must comply with regulatory obligations to Federal agencies such as the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Communications Commission, and the Federal Trade Commission. Recipients of grants, loans, or loan guarantees must use the funds within 5 years for the approved project, unless circumstances beyond their control prevent it. SEC. 604 of the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 is amended to include a clearinghouse website for rural broadband program coordination. The Secretary can use up to 5% of the budget for a national competition to create a free rural broadband clearinghouse website with resources, case studies, best practices, technology tutorials, and policy analysis. The Secretary can allocate up to 5% of the budget for a national competition to establish a free rural broadband clearinghouse website with resources, case studies, best practices, technology tutorials, and policy analysis. Additionally, the development includes rural broadband options and policies analysis, support for networks among rural communities and economic development agencies, and a comprehensive list of providers. The Secretary can allocate up to 5% of the budget for a national competition to establish a free rural broadband clearinghouse website with resources, case studies, best practices, technology tutorials, and policy analysis. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to the Committees on Agriculture evaluating the effectiveness of Federal broadband assistance programs in rural areas, including identifying areas without broadband service and tracking adoption rates. The report will evaluate possible broadband suppliers, speeds in rural areas, barriers to adoption, proposals for interagency coordination, and the adequacy of universal service support programs. The report will assess best practices for promoting broadband access in rural and underserved areas, as well as methods to coordinate efforts between the Department of Agriculture, Department of Commerce, and Federal Communications Commission to advance broadband deployment in rural areas.
